content: This is pretty common mac shortcut key for going back in browser history. Should we remove it from keyboard shortcuts?

Screenshot-2023-05-26-at-7.52.03-PM.png

We advertise it as go to default view which is not true on mac atleast.
It seems to work on Windows (Firefox) but I would think that keyboard help should just teach me either "a" (All messages) or "t" (Recent conversations) based on my preferences.

It might be OK to drop it and rely on a and t...

Though note that Esc (which also navigates to the default view) can be disabled:

Screen-Shot-2023-05-26-at-8.41.35-AM.png

This option was implemented because of a user report that they were accidentally ending up in Recent conversations when closing the compose box.
The longer story behind Esc is that many users (including me) were getting dumped into "All messages" by accident, so that is definitely something that should remain.

But that seems like something where you could also look at the user settings and customize the help. (I suppose the only danger here is that if somebody changes their settings for some reason, they will need to know to change their habits a bit, but that can be addressed by a little popup after they change the settings. I mean, actually that would be a problem now.)

I guess this is also not working for me (Desktop app on a Mac):

Screen-Shot-2023-05-26-at-9.47.47-AM.png
Yeah, browser simply handles the hotkey for going back.

I think removing it makes sense. I'm pretty sure Ctrl+[ was added along with the j/k Vim keyboard shortcuts were added, very early on. We get a lot of feedback from folks appreciating the j/k support, but I've never heard anyone mention this, and I feel like modern keyboards all have a way to do Esc pretty easily, so I don't think there's much reason to have this.

(Cmd+[ was presumably generated from translating Ctrl to Cmd like we do for Mac shortcuts in general)
This topic was moved here from #frontend > Removing cmd + [ keyboard shortcut by Tim Abbott.
Moving this here for greater visibility. If anyone reading this has ever intentionally used Zulip's Ctrl+[ or Cmd+[ keyboard shortcuts not because you were QAing Zulip, I'd be curious to hear why.
